WRITING.TITLE: 1.0 mangrove snake. This snake is a rear fanged colubrid. People often think there venom is weak and not very strong. When in actuality. There venom is quite toxic. They just have an extremely poor delivery system. One of my all time favorite species to own.

But was fine within about 3 hrs. But don #8217;t get me wrong they can be much worse or a lot less. Depending on how bad the bit is or isn #8217;t

WRITING.TEXT: Yes our locale toxicologist has AV on hand here in Houston for most African species. Coving many naja species. And all mamba species.
Shift boxes. I rarely ever have to put my hands on them
He depends on state city and county laws. For me. Yes your do need a license
It**
I have a 9 foot female as well. I #8217;ll post her later !
Lmfao !

Everyone honestly reacts differently. So it #8217;d be hard to say witch I #8217;d prefer to get bitten by if I had to lmao. But best case with the mamba here. Is simply not dying. I would be in some serious trouble if that were to happen. Although AV Is available. It would be atleast an hr before I could get vials in me. And that #8217;s the absolute best case scenario. With mambas. I try to keep hands off as much as possible. They all have shift boxes. Witch makes my life so much easier.
Personal pleasure. And also for breeding projects. I keep a lot of venomous stuff

1 bite. Only hit me with one fang and it was a tiny tiny copperhead. Didn #8217;t even go to the hospital. Just rode it out. My goal is to never get bitten. And I try to take it as seriously as I possibly can. Have bite protocol for every species I own along with my toxicologist cell Phone number so I can reach him directly with no BS.
I will try my best ! Thanks man
Male isn #8217;t too bad. Female is fuckin insane.

WRITING.TITLE: Make me babies. 1.1 Black mambas. (D. Polylepis) the male has been all over the female recently.
Make me babies. 1.1 Black mambas. (D. Polylepis) the male has been all over the female recently.

WRITING.TEXT: My passion. I love Being able To work with these animals
Thanks man !
Babies wouldn #8217;t be more deadly. It #8217;s a passion Iv had since I could walk lol

Couldn #8217;t have said it better. It takes years and tons of experience to get to this point. People think they can just jump in with no repercussion. I am permitted btw for those wondering lol. And there are several factors to take in with owning venomous animals.
That is also no true. Just a myth. Baby snakes do have control of there Venom. And it #8217;s the same toxicity as an adult. Adult bite would Be far worse. Because it yields more venom.
Exactly ! I #8217;d like to breed every species I keep atleast once

That #8217;s a shift box. Each snake has one. That allows me to do cage maintenance without getting hands on. When working with snakes such as mambas. Safety is always first. And this reduces my chance of getting bitten by about 99% lol

WRITING.TITLE: Blue or green ? Here are my 2 Gravid girls 0.1 Trimeresurus insularis (blue) and 0.1 Trimeresurus albolabris (green). My current favorite genus to own. Lots of cool breeding projects to come.

WRITING.TEXT: Yes our locale hospital here in Houston is stocked with AV for about 95% of the snakes that I keep. Including the mambas. Bite protocols are in place given I do take a bite. I have take 1 bite over the last 7 years. It was from a neonate cooperhead. She was tubed and I was removing stuck shed. She slipped out and before I Could react she caught me with one fang in the thumb. I honestly just rode the bite out. No AV or anything was required. I slept it off. Had some minor swelling and random blood vessels in my wrist out of all places started busting. But I was completely fine within a day. And didn #8217;t even miss work. Soreness was the worst part.
Either that. Or there isn #8217;t one yet

Don #8217;t get bitten lol. In all seriousness tho. Even if something doesn #8217;t have an AV. Like a squam for example. There are still certain AV that can help. But isn #8217;t designed for that snake in particular it that makes sense. But the end goal there. Is don #8217;t get bitten. Same with the genus echis
Thanks man !
Green was bred to a green. And the blue was bred to a blue

WRITING.TEXT: You say stupid. I call it a passion that Iv put years and years into. Being able to safely work with these animals. Just because you don #8217;t agree and YOU don #8217;t like it. Doesn #8217;t mean you have to call my passion stupid. And bash it.

Yes I can work with her. Pretty easily also. She #8217;s fairly laid back. Now. I never get her out just to handle tho. Only time I put hands on the snake it when she comes out for cage maintenance and or something related to it. Like maybe she needs to soak a little or whatever the case may be and I can snap a few pics. Although she #8217;s laid back. You can absolutely never underestimate ANY venomous snakes. Because it could potentially cost you your life. And as far as #8220;trust #8221; goes with her. There #8217;s not much there. She is incredibly smart and inquisitive. But really all they know is food and protect them selves. But often times I see her checking stuff out around the snake room. It #8217;s really cool to watch there behavior
She is Malayan x Indonesian cross CB 2016
About 9 foot
Thank you !
Guess the same way you #8217;d Name a dog or a cat. Pick a name You like. Although. She came from a buddy of mine who had already named it. And when he shipped her to me. I decided to keep it.

1. It #8217;s simply a passion I have had since I was a child. I think there #8217;s nothing cooler than being able to work with animals that you truly love. There #8217;s no feeling like it. Although it #8217;s taken years and years to get to the point I #8217;m at. I would never recommend someone just jumping into owning an Animal like her. Takes lots and lots of experience. 2. I have ball pythons....for her to eat (Most are dead tho lol). 3.yes bite protocols are in place
